posts.name: 4391 Programming Mentor
posts.cooked: Our auto is a big long sequential command with a series of paths and other commands we call.  When doing our first path, and ONLY when on the real field in competition, our first path following command is acting crazy.  Big delays before certain event triggers actually happen, and it’s also appearing to not react to the constraint zone we have in place halfway through the path where it should be slowing down.  It only seems to speed up and slams into reef.  Subsequent paths are working normally.  This NEVER happens in practice when not on FMS .  We are doing the PathPlanner warmup command on robot init as recommended.  Been trying all sorts of dumb things and cant get this to stop.  Any ideas please?  Thanks!

link_counts.title: Extremely Long Auto Delay at Start

posts.cooked: Quick basic idea: try running FollowPathCommand.warmupCommand(). schedule() in Robot.init to load everything up into memory before the command starts

posts.name: Dylan Li
posts.cooked:
Hi! We are actually experiencing something super super similar. Do you guys log your loop overruns? We have about an 800ms loop overrun about 1 second in auton. See quals 43 for example of our match on TBA . Does that match what is happening to your robot? Also, are you guys on a Rio 1? Thanks for posting, we’ve been stressing about why our auton works perfectly in practice but not on FMS . It also seemed to get better when we reimage the rio, but the issue came back later during competition.

Edit: I see you guys are at comp too. A temporary solution we did was to wait five seconds into autonomous to let the overrun die down. We lose a coral in auton but at least our robot doesn’t break

Edit 2: We also seemed to run fine during the load in day practice matches (where we are playing on the real field connected to FMS ). Were you guys fine for those practice matches?

We’re hitting a very similar issue too!

I have logs, and I’m viewing them in AdvantageScope.  One thing I noticed is that before the match started, the “warmup command” clearly drives to the other side of the field using pathplanner:

Warmup 1920×774 54.4 KB

Warmup 1920×774 54.4 KB

Warmup 1920×774 54.4 KB

I’m wondering if the moment when auto begins, we are starting to drive IMMEDIATELY, and I wonder if for a short period of time, the robot is still trying to drive over to the targetPose (the green robot in the picture above) before pathplanner is given the new target pose…

I.e. I can’t tell if we need to reset something after warmup of pathplanner.

Also, in my case: I noticed that autonomousInit did overrun 0.2s.

In our code, we’re loading the auto command during autonomousInit() - i.e. the expensive call to PathPlannerAuto() to load in the path.  And then we IMMEDIATELY schedule it and it instantly tries driving without any timeouts.

So another crazy hypothesis could be that we should pre-load this Auto before autonomous starts? I also like your idea above of maybe “sleeping a bit” before starting to move in auto.

posts.name: David Loh
posts.cooked:
Adding onto what Dylan said, at the same time as we reimaged our rio, we removed our autonChooser and moved getAutonomousCommand() from autonomousInit to robotInit, which may have also helped with the loop overruns.

Edit: a couple of hours after reimaging the rio, the issue returned, and we reimaged the rio again, which seemed to help for the rest of the day. We are using a rio 1.

Edit 2: to be clear, we made it so that getAutonomousCommand returns a hard-coded path planner auton, and doesn’t rely on the driver station.

posts.name: 4391 Programming Mentor
posts.cooked: Thank you I think this is where our issue may be.  We have to find a way to load our auton BEFORE autonomousInit and I think we’ll be ok.  Too late to try to add that today as eliminations just about to start but at least we have a clue where to dive in next week.

posts.name: Dylan Li
posts.cooked:
Maybe it’s not too late to try adding this in?

Auto Init Overrun Programming

posts.name: David Loh
posts.cooked: No problem! Please let us know if you find anything else that helps, as we are also trying to debug the issue. We didn’t have the warmup command before, so we’re going to try adding that tomorrow.
take a look at this Auto Init Overrun might help fix your issue
